aspect." The central character, Blossius,

Walter Hook, "because of its colonial
aspect." The central character, Blossius,

"Howe's it going?" is the
question to ask when it comes to
women's varsity squash. The
country's top twenty teams are
invited annually to compete in
the Howe Cup national championship which is sanctioned by
the United States Squash Racquets Association. • Hopkins,
which is a 'member of the
Association of Intercollegiate
Athletics for Women (AIAW),
has been invited to this prestigious weekend-long tournament
since 1978. Invitations are sent
to teams on the basis of the
previous year's performance.
Performance at Howe Cup is key
to national ranking and the Lady
Jays emerged from the 1981
games ranked 13th. However,
the Ivy Leagues and Seven Sister
schools have dominated Howe
Cup competition.
Although team standing is
important, squash is an individual sport. Members vie for the
precious ranking on the team
itself in order to participate in
the various events. For example,
only a team's top seven players
are permitted entry in the Howe

Cup tourney. Season-end AIAW
championship matches are held
on an individual basis.
In
December, Princeton hosted a
tournament for the top 16
players in the nation, and
Hopkins' own Nunzie Gould
received an invitation.
In
addition to the regular season
schedule, players scrimmage
Baltimore squash clubs. Co-captains Gould and Carole
Vannier have earned first and
second positions on the team.
As it now stands, Edith Agoff,
Kathy Cou, Natalie Kirschner,
Gail Penny, and Suzane Lau are,
ranked 3rd through 7th, respectively, on the team ladder.
In her second year as coach
of the Jays, Cathy Cramer has
only praise for the women.
Strategically difficult, squash is a
hard sport to learn and master.
In October, a mass of about 60
players came out for the team.
Attrition and cuts have compacted this to a more reasonable
23. Cramer is opposed to a
"cutting" policy but is limited
by court availability and coaching assistance. In the Jan. 29
